content.description: This is the obvious, excellent, thin crack on the south side of the "World's Greatest Boulder".  Refer to the "NE Arete" problem for directions and orientation.
content.protection: A pad and spotter, possibly...it's a little high on good holds near the top.

content.description: It is on the Book Boulders.  It is a small group of boulders a few hundred yards below The Book in the field on the south side of the trail. Starts on a jug just below the roof, and goes out left then fires out to a bad sloper and continues out to a crack to the topout.
content.protection: Good landing, one pad is good enough.

content.description: The SE corner of tghe "world's Greatest Boulder".  Refer to "NE arete for approach and orientation.  A really fun problem.

Refer to "NE" arete for directions to the "World's Greatest Boulder".  This problem slaps/laybacks up rounded, leaning rails on the NW side of the boulder.  Very short, with a good mantle to top out.  A contrived sit-start makes it a moe solid B1.

This problem is on the "World's Greatest Boulder" or "Book Boulder", which is found on the south of the trail a little beyond the turnoff for the Book.  Kind of a long boulder, size and shape of a whale, with another smaller boulder south of it.  Sme good problems, but far from the worl'ds greatest boulder.  The NE corner is a great sloper problem, which can be made a bit harder with a sit-start, or easier if one busts left to a good hold near the top instead of slapping all the way up the arete.
content.protection: standard bouldering paraphenalia; pad not really necessary

content.description:
The obvious slab on the east, with many variations possible.

[forgot to mention this is located on the "Worlds Greatest Boulder"--refer to "NE arete", #78, for directions and a description of the boulder.]
content.protection: It's high near the top, so if you are new to climbing, take that into consideration...

content.description: This problem is on the "World's Greatest Boulder"--refer to "NE arete" for approach and orientation.  It ascends the obvious  finger crack through a roof on the north side.  I haven't successfully completed the brutal finger jams from a full sit-start, and it is reasonably challenging, though much easier starting standing up.  Eliminate the upper face holds if desired.
